Award.AwardTitle: Elevated Nocturnal Convection - The Role of Microphysical Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is for participation in the Plains Elevated Convection at Night (PECAN) field campaign. PECAN will take place in the central United States in the summer of 2015. The focus of the project is on overnight thunderstorm complexes that regularly occur in the Great Plains area. A variety of observational systems will be put in place for the field experiment including multiple aircraft, mobile radars, and ground-based systems that can profile the wind and particles in the lower atmosphere. This project will provide funding for researchers to take part in the deployment of the NOAA P-3 research aircraft. The P-3 will have a variety of sensors with cloud particle probes and airborne radar as key measurements. The researchers will help collect, quality control, and analyze the data in order to study the key questions surrounding nocturnal elevated convection. The main impact from this research will be better forecasts of overnight storms, which often come with severe winds and flooding rains. The project will also help train the future generation of scientists by involving multiple graduate students in the research.

The steering committee for the PECAN campaign has identified four main research topics to be addressed: 1) Nocturnal convection initiation and early evolution of mesoscale convective clusters; 2) Bore and other wave-like disturbances; 3) Dynamics and microphysics of nocturnal mesoscale convective systems; 4) Prediction of nocturnal convection initiation and evolution. This research will focus on the third topic. In-situ cloud microphysical data, ground based and airborne radar data, and the results of numerical modeling simulations will be used to test the main hypothesis; microphysical cooling processes in developing and mature stratiform regions of mesoscale convective systems force downdraft circulations that create bore and mesoscale gravity wave features on the stable nocturnal boundary layer that in turn focuses, organizes and maintains future convective activity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summertime thunderstorms over the U.S. Great Plains often form during the late afternoon, but persist well after dark and into early morning hours.  After sunset, storms organize into distinct lines, during which time slow-moving storm complexes can often produce flash floods, severe winds, or occasional hail or tornadoes.  How thunderstorms persist at night long after the source of their energy, the sun, has set is an open question, although many hypotheses have been forwarded related to the presence of low-level jetstreams, gravity waves and atmospheric bores. The 2015 Plains Elevated Convection at Night (PECAN) field campaign was designed to collect ground- and aircraft-based observations to advance understanding of nocturnal convection in conditions where the lowest layer of the atmosphere (the boundary layer) has stabilized at night, a low-level jetstream flows from (approximately) south to north above the boundary layer, and the largest Convective Available Potential Energy (CAPE, a measure of thunderstorm buoyancy) is found above the stable boundary layer. A key goal of PECAN was to determine how nocturnal convection within elevated thunderstorm complexes (called mesoscale convective systems, MCSs) maintain their structure and intensity over long times in the absence of surface-based CAPE, and without a balance between cold-pool-generated vorticity and vorticity associated with environmental shear (a dynamic criteria for upright, surface-based thunderstorms).

 

The NOAA-P-3 aircraft was a key instrumentation platform used during PECAN.  This aircraft flew directly behind the thunderstorm lines, focusing on the region of the storm referred to as the transition zone, which divides stratiform precipitation to the west and the line of thunderstorms to the east.  The PIs of this proposal flew on the aircraft, and were responsible for quality control and analysis of the NOAA P-3 microphysical measurements and subsequent analysis of those data in context of storm kinematics and dynamics. As part of this work, the PIs also were responsible for producing kinematic flow analyses by combining data from the NOAA P-3 tail Doppler radars with ground-based Doppler radars. The PIs also conducted complimentary numerical modeling studies of the storms associated with elevated convection.

The overarching hypothesis motivating this PECAN research was that nocturnal elevated convection is maintained by gravity wave forcing. Specifically, the PIs hypothesized that microphysical cooling processes in developing and mature stratiform regions of MCSs force downdraft circulations that create mesoscale gravity wave features on the stable nocturnal boundary layer that in turn focus, organize and maintain future thunderstorm activity. The aircraft microphysical data, air- and ground-based Doppler radar observations and modeling studies conducted during the research phase of this work were designed to test this hypothesis.

Overall, six publications from this research are either in print or production. A collaborative paper by all PECAN PIs described the PECAN campaign and early findings. In a second paper, data from the NOAA P-3 and another airborne radar system were synthesized to produce a quad-Doppler analysis of a squall line, yielding a detailed three-dimensional kinematic analysis of its structure. A numerical simulation of the squall line complemented the pseudo-quad-Doppler analysis. These analyses revealed how the convective line interacted with an upper-tropospheric jet stream. A third paper introduced new tools for quantitative statistical comparison of observations and numerical simulations including the horizontal variability within storms, the frequency of occurrence of specific reflectivity or wind conditions, and the average altitude where these conditions occur. The tool was demonstrated using airborne quad-Doppler radar observations of an MCS and a numerical simulation of the event. During PECAN, airborne radar and optical array probe data were collected within 42 spiral ascents/descents of the NOAA P-3 across various regions of six MCSs at multiple stages of system development. In the fourth paper, multiple-Doppler syntheses of the wind and reflectivity fields within the PECAN 20 June 2015 storm were used to understand the microphysical and thermodynamic characteristics observed in the spirals in the context of the storm reflectivity and kinematic structure. In the fifth paper, statistical analyses were performed of the microphysical and thermodynamic structures observed in 37 PECAN spirals. The thermodynamic and microphysical structure of the MCSs were analyzed in the context of three MCS regions, namely the transition zone, the enhanced stratiform rain region, and the anvil region. These two papers provided direct evidence that evaporation of water droplets and sublimation of ice in the transition zone could create downdrafts required to support gravity waves on the stable boundary layer. The sixth paper examined the role of downdrafts in the transition zone in creating waves on the boundary layer beneath the transition zone, and the effect of these flows on the convection.

This research resulted in two Ph.D. dissertations and three Masters Theses. Overall, the research contributed to the professional training of 5 graduate students and two undergraduate students, and provided opportunities for additional students to participate in a major field program.
